baseline_groups.claim_summary: The one-quarter hazard rate (fraction of new hires separating within one quarter) has declined significantly over time, accounting for much of the overall decline in worker turnover.
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline coefficient -0.0745 (p<0.0001). This is a DESCRIPTIVE finding: the one-quarter hazard rate declined by ~7.5pp per unit of time trend over 1999-2018. Not a causal study. 93% of specs negative, 88% significant at 5%. All alternative outcome measures show similar declining trends.

global_notes: Descriptive/accounting paper documenting declining worker turnover. NOT a causal study -- no treatment or policy intervention. The time_trend coefficient captures the secular decline in short-duration employment spells. The decline is pervasive across demographics, industries, and geographies. Post-2010 the trend appears to have flattened. 5 permutation placebo tests all show non-significant coefficients, confirming the real trend.
